metadata.synopsis: Sgt. Tom Hardy (Bruce Willis) denounces his partner, Jimmy Detillo (Robert Pastorelli), for brutally interrogating a suspect. After Jimmy falls to his death from a bridge, Tom is transferred from homicide to the river rescue team. Two years later, the bodies of murdered young women begin turning up in the water -- all of whom were previously romantically linked to Tom. With the help of his new partner, Jo Christman (Sarah Jessica Parker), Tom sets out to find the killer.

reviews: Although the basic concept is intriguing and the serial killer's methods are memorable, the pacing is noticeably faulty.
Herringston's return to his hometown is no triumph, striking out at every turn, and failing to go the distance.
Striking Distance's failure is, in the end, especially disappointing given the first act's effectiveness and potential...
Like the box of generic corn flakes, Striking Distance isn't so terrible, but you'll forget it the second you're done with it. [Blu-ray]
A troubled production (reshoots, release-date postponements) that turned out to be surprisingly watchable.
One of Bruce Willis' most disposable and formulaic action potboilers. I'm a big fan of the Willis, and even I have no patience for "Striking Distance."
A mess, although the stars do what they can with the scattershot screenplay
Not one of Willis' best efforts; very formulaic and uninteresting.
Fails to deliver anything remotely original.
If "Striking Distance" were a book, it could be called a good read. Instead, it's a painless watch.
